subject: Re: [junit] a question about abstract/parameterised tests
msgSnippet: ... I didn t understand this question. True or false: you want to create a test suite consisting of tests for all the implementations of an interface. (Please
messageBody:
>So said Chris Dollin on 2003-08-04 --------------------
>We have an interface (Graph) with multiple implementations (A and B). [Some
>names have been changed to avoid complications.] I have a test case
>AbstractTestGraph with an abstract method Graph getGraph(), where the
>tests test the Graph(s) that getGraph() returns, and TestA/TestB define
>getGraph() to return instances of A/B as appropriate. So far, so good, and
>just as suggested in one of the Junit documents. The code for each test
>case is nice and short.
>
>Well ... I lied about A and B; it's more like A, B, C, and X. And likely to
>be more, since Y and Z exist but may not be properly included in the
>test suite at the moment.
>
>(1) How can I write a test generator which takes A.class, X.class etc as
>arguments and constructs the necessary suite?

I didn't understand this question.

True or false: you want to create a test suite consisting of tests for all the implementations of an interface. (Please answer.)

The obvious-to-me code
>
> public static TestCase makeMyTest( final Class someGraph )
> {
> class TestSomeGraph extends AbstractTestGraph
> {
> public TestSomeGraph( String name ) { super( name ); }
> public static TestSuite suite() { return new TestSuite(
>TestSomeGraph ); }
> public Graph getGraph()
> { return someGraph.getConstructor( new Class[] {}
>).newInstance( new Object [] {} ); }
> }
> }

This appears to try to build concrete test cases (http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?AbstractTestCases) on the fly given an abstract test case. I have never thought of doing this before, but it makes sense.

Assuming that this is what you're trying to do, then I assume you have:

* An abstract test case GraphTest
* An interface Graph
* Implementations of Graph

You would like to generate a test suite consisting of XTestCase for each implementation XGraph of Graph where XTestCase creates an instance of XGraph to test.

This is a neat question. Let me think about this.

>So ... am I dead-ended in the wrong alley? Missing something obvious?
>Missing something subtle? Any advice would be welcome. If I have to
>hack junit source code I will, but I feel that surely I don't need to ...

I don't think you are. Dynamic invocation handlers might be the order of the day, or something... This seems to be easy to do in a dynamic language like Smalltalk. :)

Take care.
